cards.front: What is the formula relating resistance to material properties and geometry?
cards.back:
R = ρL/A

Where:
• ρ = resistivity (Ω·m)
• L = length (m)
• A = cross-sectional area (m²)

cards.front: What color represents the digit '4' in the resistor color code?
cards.back:
Yellow

Mnemonic: 'Better Be Right Or Your Great Big Venture Goes West'
0=Black, 1=Brown, 2=Red, 3=Orange, 4=Yellow, 5=Green, 6=Blue, 7=Violet, 8=Gray, 9=White

cards.front: What does a gold tolerance band indicate?
What are the three power formulas for a resistor?
cards.back:
P = VI = I²R = V²/R

All three give the same result; use whichever matches your known quantities.

cards.front: Why is 50% derating recommended for resistor power ratings?
cards.back:
To ensure reliability and long life:
• Prevents overheating
• Accounts for ambient temperature
• Compensates for manufacturing variation
• Extends component lifetime significantly

cards.front: What is the temperature coefficient (α) and what are typical values?
cards.back:
α measures resistance change per degree Celsius.

R(T) = R₀[1 + α(T - T₀)]

Typical values:
• Copper: +3900 ppm/°C
• Carbon: -500 ppm/°C
• Nichrome: +100 ppm/°C
• Constantan: ±20 ppm/°C

cards.front: Why does carbon have a NEGATIVE temperature coefficient while metals have positive?
cards.back:
Metals: Higher T → more atomic vibrations → more electron scattering → higher R

Carbon (semiconductor-like): Higher T → more charge carriers freed → lower R

Opposite mechanisms!

cards.front: What is the advantage of metal film resistors over carbon film?
cards.back:
Metal film advantages:
• Tighter tolerance (1% vs 5%)
• Lower temperature coefficient
• Lower noise (less current noise)
• Better long-term stability

Trade-off: Higher cost (≈10×)

cards.front: Why are wirewound resistors unsuitable for high-frequency applications?
cards.back:
The coiled wire construction creates parasitic inductance.

At high frequencies (>50kHz), this inductance dominates, making the 'resistor' behave more like an inductor.

Use film resistors for RF applications.

cards.front: A 4.7kΩ resistor has bands: Yellow-Violet-Red-Gold. Verify this using the color code.
cards.back:
Yellow = 4 (1st digit)
Violet = 7 (2nd digit)
Red = ×100 (multiplier)
Gold = ±5% (tolerance)

Value = 47 × 100 = 4700Ω = 4.7kΩ ± 5% ✓

cards.front: What is the E24 series and why is it used?
cards.back:
E24 is a standard set of 24 resistor values per decade, spaced ~10% apart.

Values: 10, 11, 12, 13, 15, 16, 18, 20, 22, 24, 27, 30, 33, 36, 39, 43, 47, 51, 56, 62, 68, 75, 82, 91

Allows any resistance ±10% with standard stock.

cards.front: What determines whether a resistor is 'ohmic' or 'non-ohmic'?
cards.back:
Ohmic: V-I relationship is linear (constant R)
• Most metal and carbon resistors at normal operating conditions

Non-ohmic: R varies with V, I, or other conditions
• Thermistors, varistors, light-dependent resistors
• Any resistor under extreme conditions
